projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A NEW DISPUTATION Betweene the two Lordly Bi≈øhops, YORKE and CANTERBVRY.
With a Di≈øcour≈øe of many pa≈ø≈øages which have happened to them, before and ≈øince that they were committed to the Tower of LONDON.
Being very nece≈ø≈øary for ob≈øervation, and well worth the Reading.
Written in Engli≈øh PROSE by Laurence Price, February the 15. 1642.

div.head: A New DISPVTATION Betweene the two Lordly Bi≈øhops, YORKE and CANTERBURY.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: FEllow and friend as a man may ≈øay, you'r well overtaken; who would have thought to have ≈øeene you here at this time of the day?

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Preth√©e York be medling with ≈øome others matters, and talke not to me. I am not thy fellow yet; and thou knowe≈øt I was never thy friend, tis wel for you that you are ≈øo light-hearted, I tell you truly I am heavy.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p:
Why Canterbury, if I may not be ≈øo bold as to call you fellow nor friend, yet I am ≈øure we are neighbours; how long ever 'twill la≈øt I cannot tell: and whereas you ≈øay you are very heavy (if I am not much ‚Ä¢ i≈øtaken)
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
You will be made lighter by the head before three moneths come to an end, I am ≈øure you have well enough de≈øerved for it.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Neighbour Yorke, if you will be ≈øo cal'd, here we are both forth-comming though not comming forth, if thou ha≈øt any thing to charge me with, ≈øpeake thy mind and ≈øpare not, I feare th√©e not.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: And ≈øhall I ≈øpeake my mind freely?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: I am in doubt I ≈øhall make you angry?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: Then Canterbury marke what I ≈øhall ≈øay to thee, I verily thinke if thou were rewarded an≈øwerable to thy deeds, thou ≈øhoulde≈øt be ≈øerved as the two Romi≈øh Prie≈øts were in January, which were benefactors for the Pope.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: Thus, fir≈øt they tooke ≈øhipping at Newgate, afterwards ≈øayled up Holborne, and came a ≈øhore at Tyburne.

p.hi: And have I de≈øerved to be drawne hang'd and quartered?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: If thou were as ≈øure to have it as thou ha≈øt de≈øerv'd for it, thy turne would be the next.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p:
I wonder Yorke why thou ≈øhoulde≈øt
be ≈øo ambitious, and to pa≈ø≈øe ra≈øh iudgment again≈øt me? thou art like him that can di≈øcerne a little mote in another mans eye; but thou can≈øt not ≈ø√©e a beame in thine own eye: for any thing I can perceive, our ca≈øes are both a like, I am in the Tower of London, ≈øo are you, I am here kept a Pri≈øoner, ≈øo are you, I am like to ≈øuffer death for my mi≈ødeeds, and ≈øo are you. Wherefore then ≈øhould you not rather ≈øtudy to cure your own di≈øea≈øes, then to apply a play≈øter to my wound.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: Stay, ≈øtay, a little my little Lord, you put me in mind of wounds and grievances, I pray you tell me one thing if you can remember it, how hath your body fared ≈øince your Doctor gave you the purge, which made you vomit up the Cro≈ø≈øe-keyes and the Miter? me thinkes you looke very co≈øtive upon the matters?

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Now you ≈øpeake of my lookes, have you forgot my Lord, how the Devill made two lookes over Lincolne? I would wi≈øh you to beware the third, lea≈øt you come home by w√©eping cro≈ø≈øe.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p:
De'e heare me Canterbury, ≈øince your mind runs ≈øo much upon cro≈ø≈øes, I can tell ≈øuch ≈øtrange newes of a Cro≈ø≈øe, which I think will cro≈ø≈øe your humour to heare it. It is for
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
certaine ≈øpoken, that Cheape-≈øide Cro≈ø≈øe is quite defunct, and ≈øtands like one for≈øaken of her former Solicitors.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Why, what have they done to Cheape-≈øide Cro≈ø≈øe? I thought that had not offended any body?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: It ≈øeemes it hath offended ≈øome body, For I am ≈øure they have torne downe part of the portraiture of the body of Chri≈øt, and the Cardinals Cro≈øier ≈øtaffe, and the Crowne that was placed upon the Virgin Maries head.

p.hi: Now by my Holy-dame, I thinke that they were no Papi≈øts, that did it, but how can you approve this to be true, I am ≈øure that you were not there to ≈ø√©e it?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p:
Are you ≈øo hard of beliefe, that you cannot beleeve any thing to be true unle≈ø≈øe you ≈øee it? Then you will not beleeve that the two Popi≈øh Prie≈øts were drawne hang'd and quartered for offending the Kings Laws; who≈øe heads were no ≈øooner ≈øet upon London Bridge, but Bensteed your young watch-man turn'd his towards the Tower, expecting a third man. Then you will not beleeve that the Lord Digby is gone beyond Sea? Then you will not beleeve that Colonell Lunsford is taken, If you will not beleeve nothing but what
you ≈øee, it is in vaine to tell you any newes at all.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: But are you in mind that the di≈øfiguring of Cheape-≈øide Cro≈ø≈øe, is a greater di≈øta≈øte to me then it is to your ≈øelfe?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: It't plea≈øe your gracele≈ø≈øe grace my little Lord, you know that I ever hated Papi≈øtry from the beginning; for which cau≈øe you cau≈øed me to ≈øuffer a long time impri≈øonment. Moreover you thought to have ≈øeene an end of my life, but now I may chance to live to ≈øee your end.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: You talke like one that is overioy'd, but tell me one thing at your lei≈øure, have you given in your an≈øwer to the charge, which was the other day layd in again≈øt you at the Parliament? or have you never ≈øeene the Welch-mans Prote≈øtation?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: 1. I would have you an≈øwer me to this que≈øtion, and then I ≈øhall an≈øwer you the better? What newes doe you heare from Rome? hath your gho≈øtly father the Pope ever a pardon in ≈øtore for you? are you ≈øure that when you dye you ≈øhall be Canonized for a Saint? re≈øolve me that que≈øtion Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Me thinks your tongue runs a little too fa≈øt York, have you any more que≈øtions to aske me?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: Yes, Yes, more I thinke then you will be willing to an≈øwer to.

p.hi: Let me heare your excellent wits; tis very well knowne that I have an≈øwered too many great matters in my time, therefore I make no doubt but I ≈øhall be ready to give you ≈øatisfaction to the full.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: Then I would have you tell me what you heare from the Cardinals, Monks, Fryers, Nuns, Popi≈øh Prie≈øts, Je≈øuites, Seminaries, and Seducers in Rome, and other Countries, are they all friends with you? Is your grace in ≈øuch high favour with them, that they will ≈øend ≈øome of their Agents privily to convey you out of this ≈øtrong Tower. They intend ≈øure a practice, let them take heed of the London Prentices, for Ben≈øteeds death is not forgotten.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Fye Yorke forbeare, thou talke≈øt to me in ≈øuch a rayling manner, that although I can, I will not an≈øwer th√©e; therefore re≈øt thy ≈øelfe content for this, I am per≈øwaded to that, if all thy faults were written in thy fore-head, thou woulde≈øt appeare to be as bad, as who's wor≈øt.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p:
Canterbury, if you are weary of my talking, I would al≈øo have you to be weary of your wicked deeds, and labour to ≈øerve
your Maker as a true Prote≈øtant ought to doe, and to be faithfull to the Kings Maje≈øty, and the Honourable Hou≈øes of Parliament; in ≈øo doing, you may have peace of Con≈øcience in this life, and after death, your fins may be remitted, through the merits of our Saviour.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Harke, harke, there is a Me≈ø≈øenget comes, which hath brought me tydings that my dinner is ready, ≈øo Yorke adieu far this time.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: Canterbury farewell, remember the la≈øt coun≈øell that I gave you, and as for my part I conclude, Hony ≈øoit qui mal I pence.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Stay Yorke, yet a little longer, I have one que≈øtion more to aske th√©e, which I had almo≈øt quite forgot.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: I thought you were troubled with the ≈øimples, you have ≈øo many things to think on, that I thinke you'l forget every thing are it be long: what would you ≈øay to me if you could ≈øpeake?

p.hi: Tell me this one thing in courte≈øie.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: What thing is that?

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: What is the rea≈øon that ≈øo many Countrymen came up to London lately? I heare that thou≈øands of men came up in troopes, ≈øome on foot, and ≈øome on hor≈øe back. What was the meaning of their comming?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: Sure enough Camerbury, they came not for any good will they bare to you.

p.hi: Why ≈øhould they beare me any ill will?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: They ≈øay you have cau≈øed them to have wor≈øhipped Idols, and that you would erect new Cro≈ø≈øes, with Popi≈øh Pictures about them, and that they were forced to ≈øet up Altars in their church by your means, The≈øe are things which Prote≈øtants neither can, nor wil indure.

p.hi: Why, doth the Law lye in their hands?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: For certaine they made Petitions to the honourable Hou≈øes of Parliament; to the end, that they would have all the Bi≈øhops put downe for your ≈øake.

p.hi: And doe you under≈øtand that all the Bi≈øhops ≈øhall be put downe?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: Yea, all the Popi≈øh Bi≈øhops.

p.hi: Then what thinke you will become of all the Romi≈øh Catholikes?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: The Prie≈øts and Fryers may take their chance,
And walke a journey into France;
The Je≈øuites they may trudge to Spaine,
The Papi≈øts all may packe to Rome,
And ≈øtay there till the day of doome.

sp.speaker: Cant.

l.hi: If all the≈øe things you live to ≈øee,

sp.l: Then will a merry England bee.

div.head: Enter a poore Mu≈øitioner with a new SONG.

l.hi: May it plea≈øe both your graces to heare a new Song,
In which on my word I meane no body wrong.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Is't worth the hearing?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I hope it will give your Lord≈øhips content.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: Come lets heare your Song.

div.opener: Here beginneth the Song, to the tune of, Banks his Bill of Fare.

lg.l: I Am a poore man and ≈øcarce worth a ≈øhilling,
As unto my neighbours is too too well knowne,
Yet to live upright in the world I am willing,
I covet for nothing but what is mine owne:
2. And now in the fir≈øt place to tell you my mind,
For fal≈øe-hearted people I care not a ≈øtraw,
This is my conceit by experience I find,

l.hi: There's none but offenders that feareth the Law.

lg.l: I am not in que≈øtion cal'd for my Religion,
From every vile Sect I my ≈øelfe can with-hold,
Both Papi≈øt and Athei≈øt I hold in deri≈øion,
Ile not wrong my con≈øcience for lucre of gold:
4. My tongue I will governe by the line of rea≈øon,
From every di≈ø≈øembler my≈øelfe Ile withdraw.
I hate all ≈øuch Rebels that dares to ≈øpeake Trea≈øon,

l.hi: There's none but offenders that feareth the Law.

lg.l: I marvaile what harme hath old Cheape-≈øide Cro≈ø≈øe done,
That ≈øome meer mechanicks hath wrought it ≈øpight,
To disfigure Picture of Mary and her Son,
And dare not to ≈øhew forth their heads by day-light:
6. They al≈øo have pul'd down the Cro≈øier Staffe
Which once was fa≈øt plac'tin the Cardinals claw,
This ≈øport cannot chu≈øe but make Lucifer laugh,

l.hi: There's none but offenders that feareth the Law.

lg.l: One thing above all the re≈øt I doe admire
Why ≈øo many vulgars are in an uproare?
To put downe the Bi≈øhops is that they de≈øire.
Although they can ≈øhew no good rea≈øon wherefore:
8. But now to conclude lea≈øt I ≈øhould you offend,
And you for my Song would no money me draw,
Ile ≈øhut up my Pipes and ≈øo make an end,

l.hi: There's none but offenders that feareth the Law.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.p: Why there's no hurt at all in this Song upon my word.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: If all that reads Pamphlets, and ≈øings Ballads about the City of London and in the Country, did no wor≈øe then this, I ≈øhould bee a great deale better plea≈øed with them: Hold there is ≈øomething for thy reward.

lg.l: My Lords I thanke you both, although your lives ≈øtands in jeopardy.
The Fidler hopes to live ≈øo long, to ≈øee your heeles at liberty.
